summary: This document is an email chain from August 2019 between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and attorney Teri Gibbs, coordinating interviews and travel for two clients (victims) who reported being assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein in 2004. It discusses scheduling interviews, a hearing regarding the dismissal of Epstein's indictment after his death, and the provision of victim services.

persons.name: Teri Gibbs
persons.context: Attorney coordinating interviews and travel for two clients who are alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein. She communicates with the U.S. Attorney's office regarding scheduling and logistics.

persons.name: Colleen Mullen
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York involved in coordinating victim interviews and travel arrangements for the Epstein case.

persons.name: Arick Fudali
persons.context: New York attorney mentioned as accompanying a victim (Ms. [redacted]) to a meeting with the U.S. Attorney's office.

persons.name: Lisa Bloom
persons.context: Attorney cc'd on emails regarding victim reports against Jeffrey Epstein, indicating her involvement or interest in the case.

persons.name: Judge Berman
persons.context: Judge who scheduled a hearing regarding the dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his death, and who indicated victims could be heard.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier who was the subject of the criminal case (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)); the victims reported being assaulted by him.

connections.description: Attorney for victims coordinating with Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding client interviews, travel, and case logistics.
Colleagues working together; Fudali is described as the New York attorney who will accompany a victim to a meeting.
Both are attorneys cc'd on case-related emails, suggesting a professional association.
Gibbs represents clients who are alleged victims of Epstein, placing her in an adversarial legal relationship with the deceased accused.
Mullen is a prosecutor for the U.S. Attorney's office handling the criminal case against Epstein.

events.title: Hearing on Dismissal of Epstein Indictment
events.description: Judge Berman scheduled a hearing regarding the dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein in light of his death. The order indicated victims could be heard directly or through counsel.

events.title: Scheduled In-Person Victim Interview
events.description: A victim (Ms. [redacted]) is scheduled for an in-person interview with the U.S. Attorney's office at 12 p.m., accompanied by attorney Arick Fudali.

events.title: Scheduled Video Conference Victim Interview
events.description: A victim located in Japan (Ms. [redacted]) is scheduled for a video conference interview with the U.S. Attorney's office at 5 p.m. EST.

events.title: Alleged Assaults by Epstein
events.description: Two clients of Teri Gibbs believe they were assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein in or around June 2004.

locations: Courtroom 178, 500 Pearl Street courthouse, New York, NY
One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Two new clients of attorney Teri Gibbs came forward in August 2019, alleging they were assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein in or around June 2004.

The U.S. Attorney's office (Southern District of New York) was actively coordinating interviews with these victims following Epstein's death, including one in-person in New York and one via video conference from Japan.
A hearing was scheduled for August 27, 2019, before Judge Berman to address the dismissal of the indictment against Epstein after his death, with provisions for victims to be heard.
The correspondence shows the prosecution offering victim services, including counseling and travel assistance, to the alleged victims.
The victims' attorneys provided photographs from 2004 to the prosecution and asked if their clients appeared in any photographs seized from Epstein's home.
